He passed away in the 20th year, and an edict was issued to posthumously title him Great Wisdom Chan Master and bury him north of Yique.
Tens of thousands of people attended the funeral.
Zhongshu Shilang Yan Tingzhi personally participated in the mourning rites, as if he were a disciple, and also composed a stele inscription.
Chan Master Shenxiu was a prodigy in the Chan school. Although he had Chan practice and received the emperor's respect, he never gathered disciples or opened a Dharma gate.
When Puzhao first transmitted the teachings in the capital city for more than 20 years, people all looked up to him.

At first, Fawang went to Dongluo and summoned his disciples to announce the time of his passing. The Minister of War Zhang Jun, the Minister of the Guards Fang Guan, and the Minister of Rites Wei Zhi always had faith in him. On that day, they all went to him in advance.
Fawang then ascended the hall and expounded to his disciples, saying:
The time of my passing is drawing near, and I will bid farewell to you all here.
After a long while, Zhang said to Fang:ğŸ”½The master's appearance is as usual, and his words are as usual.
I have been taking gold elixir since I was young, and I have never faced death.
After saying this, Zhang then secretly left.
Fu suddenly said to Fang:
I have been friends with Zhang for many years.
Zhang is about to suffer an extraordinary calamity, and his reputation and integrity will all be damaged.
If he had finished this Dharma assembly earlier, it would have been enough to avoid disaster.
What a pity!
He then held Fang's hand and said:
You will surely become a famous minister of the new dynasty. Strive for it!
After saying this, he passed away.
Later, when Zhang Jun fell into the enemy camp and accepted their false titles, while Fang Yi served two dynasties and established great integrity, all of this was due to Fu's words.
Shi Xingsi, whose surname was Liu, was a man from Luling.
He was nurtured with integrity and had a sincere and honest nature.

After leaving the dust [of the world], he received the precepts and further sought perfection. He broke the sharp corners [of arrogance] and carved away the rough [impurities], his aspiration was natural.
He went to see Chan Master Dajian in Shaoyang and, in a single word, had his doubts completely resolved, as if enlightened.

Having understood his original mind, the earth spirits alternately announced his return. He then went back to Jizhou to spread the teaching, and the hall was filled with Chan practitioners from all directions.

On the thirteenth day of the twelfth month in the twenty-eighth year of Kaiyuan, he passed away in his hometown. The emperor posthumously bestowed the title of Great Master and the stupa name Guizhen.

His stupa was leveled during the Huichang persecution, but later his Dharma heirs rebuilt it.ğŸ”½Tang Dynasty Biographies of Eminent Monks, Volume 1, Chapter 1: Biographies of Eminent Monks of the Tang Dynasty, Part 1. Compiled by Shi Daoshi of Ximing Temple in Chang'an.
Shi Puan, with the surname Feng, was from Hedong, Puzhou.
Even as a child, he was naturally lofty and extraordinary. He left secular life and ascended the ordination platform, following the sutras and precepts.
When studying the texts and contemplating their meaning, he was vastly different from the ordinary flow [of people].
He first heard that Shenxiu was at Yuquan Temple in Jingzhou, so Puan went to study under him for six years.
Shenxiu marveled at him and bestowed all his teachings upon him.
During the Jiuzhi era, Empress Wu summoned Shenxiu to the Eastern Capital to discuss the Way, and he recommended Puan. He was then ordained as a monk.
After Shenxiu's death, those who admired Buddhism in the world all took him as their teacher.
When Emperor Zhongzong heard that Shenxiu was of advanced age, he issued an edict ordering Puan to succeed his teacher and lead his Dharma assembly.
In the twenty-third year of Kaiyuan, the emperor ordered Puan to reside in the capital city.

At that time, the princes and nobles vied to come and pay homage. Puan was stern and spoke little. Those who came found it difficult to see his expression of joy and peace. The people from far and near especially valued him for this.
In the twenty-seventh year, he passed away at Xingtang Temple in the capital.
He was eighty-nine years old.
At that time, the people of the capital city who came to pay their respects all wore the robes of disciples.
There was an edict granting the posthumous title of Great Illumination Chan Master.
When he was buried, Henan Yin Pei Kuan and his wife and children all wore hemp and placed themselves in the ranks of the disciples.
The whole city wept as they sent him off, and the neighborhoods became empty because of it.
Pei's heavy grief upon Zhizhe's passing had its reasons.

Zhizhe's propagation of the Dharma was accompanied by much spiritual wonder, which Pei all witnessed. He also obtained the mind seal, and his devotion became even deeper. At the time, many ridiculed him.
Pei visited Zhizhe day and night, observing the propriety of a disciple without the slightest deviation.
One day, Pei visited Zhizhe, who was hanging up his robe. Zhizhe suddenly knew that his disciple Yixing had passed away.

When Zhizhe finally passed away, Pei's grief was as if he had lost a close relative. He wore hemp and followed the coffin on foot out of the city, his wife and children doing the same. The criticism from the officials and gentlemen arose from this.
The author says:ğŸ”½The feelings of people have love and hatred. Those who love do not see what is hateful, and those who hate do not see what is lovable.
The myriad things are complex, and one should follow their love and hatred. The way of moderation is to love what is lovable and not hate what is unlovable.
Those who love him are gentlemen, those who hate him are petty people. If love is not based on the Way, then it is the sickness of a gentleman.
Pei Yin wore his cap and robes in the imperial presence, and his duties were in his own hands. He did not avoid secret actions, and openly removed timely slander. How appropriate!
It is like monks indulging in worldly affairs. Why not abandon their kasaya robes and wear court robes?
If they truly attain the Way, they will eventually discard their shoes. What is there that is unacceptable?
If Kuan did not draw his hairpin, how could he be contrary to propriety at the gate of the hill?
If Kuan practices the Way of the transcendent, then what is there to punish?
The enlightened person has a broad perspective, and there is nothing that is unacceptable.

The Biography of Huai Rang of Guanyin Terrace in Nanyue during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Huai Rang of Guanyin Terrace in Nanyue during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Huai Rang, with the secular surname Du, was from Ankang in Jinzhou.

At the age of ten, he naturally loved Buddhist scriptures. He had a brilliant and extraordinary appearance, and a unique spiritual manifestation. Those who recognized him predicted that he would leave the household life and not be a noble in the secular world.
The auspicious omens of the arrival of the human treasure, the celebration of the nation's boundless joy, are comparable to the qilin, phoenix, tortoise, and dragon, without a myriad number.

Heaven and earth have no complete merit, the sequence of qi has fullness and emptiness, the warp and woof are incomplete and broken, and the supplementation is insufficient. They are all secretly supported, only those who are to be liberated illuminate its principle, it is not known by the ordinary and mediocre.
At the age of twenty, he went to Yuquan Temple in Jingnan, served Vinaya Master Hengjing, and then shaved his head and received full ordination.
He sighed and said:

As for those who leave the household life, it is for the unconditioned Dharma. There is nothing superior to it in the heavens or the human realm. The sutra calls it leaving the four crossroads and sitting in the open field.
At that time, Chan Master Tan encouraged him to go to Mount Song and meet Master An. An enlightened him, and he then entered Caohouxi to visit Master Neng.
Master Neng was delighted, without fragrance or stench, the vast and great ocean of the vast and great waves?
The harmony of the great music of the combined performance of the Shao and Hu?
Letting him deeply enter tranquil concentration, abiding in the immovable Way-place, is like this.
When Master Neng's great affairs were completed, Let ascended Hengyue and stayed at Guanyin Terrace.
At that time, there was a monk named Xuan who was imprisoned. He thought of Master Let and wished for his protection.
Let knew early on and encouraged him. The monk escaped danger and said it was the Sakyamuni Avalokitesvara, thus obtaining this name. It is also from this.
When his transformative influence was about to end, his Dharma disciples were named Dao Jun and Dao Yi, who all ascended the hall and saw the profound principles.
Later, Master Yi shook the Dharma drum in Hongzhou, and his disciple-followers were named Wei Kuan and Huai Hui.
When Master Yi's great affairs were about to end, he said to Kuan and others:
My teacher's Way lies in the wondrous. It is always without waiting, and arrives without abiding. The collected tasks are complete.
Born from the golden mouth, transformed by the Dharma, he is my son and your grandson. How can there be an end to the transmission of a single lamp?
Hui Neng was born in the second year of Yifeng and died on the tenth day of the eighth month in the third year of Tianbao at Mount Heng, at the age of sixty-eight, with forty-eight years as a monk.
Yizhong built a stupa for him on a separate peak.
During the Yuanhe period, Kuan and Hui reached the capital and promoted their original school. The Dharma gate was greatly opened, transmitting hundreds of thousands of lamps.
The vast and prosperous Dharma treasures of the capital and summer flourished here.
In the eighth year, the magistrate of Hengyang, Linghu Quan, asked about the previous traces of Hui Neng. Quan donated his clothes and wealth to hold a memorial feast.
From then on, every year in the eighth month, it became the Avalokitesvara Memorial Day.
In the Baili period, he was posthumously titled Great Wisdom Chan Master, and the stupa was named Supreme Wheel.
During the Yuanhe period, the permanent attendant Gui Deng wrote a stele inscription.

Tang Dynasty, Great An-guo Temple, Laá¹…kÄ Monastery, Ling-zhuo's Biography Tang Dynasty, Great An-guo Temple, Laá¹…kÄ Monastery, Ling-zhuo's Biography, Dharma Play, Shi Ling-zhuo, whose secular surname was Liu, was from Ba-xi in Mian-zhou.
At the age of ten, he aspired to study and thus left home to become a monk. He received full ordination and sought teachers, traveling no less than a thousand li.
At the age of forty, he specialized in the Vinaya teachings and also lectured on the Nirvana Sutra, diligently transmitting the precepts and scriptures.
In his later years, he asked the Chan Master Da-zhao for instruction and was enlightened to the Chan teachings. He guarded his will with increasing diligence.
Later, he went to Chang-an and widely spread the Chan teachings. Those who admired the Way and sought a teacher numbered no less than a thousand, like fish and dragons gathering in a deep pool.

On the tenth day of the fourth month in the fifth year of Tian-bao, at the time of the monkey hour, he passed away at the Stone Laá¹…kÄ SÅ«tra Monastery of An-guo Temple, at the age of fifty-six, and thirty-six years as a monk.
Before his death, there were many strange occurrences in the temple, which were signs of the collapse of the pillars and beams of the Dharma gate.
He sat in the full lotus position and passed away peacefully.

Three weeks later, they cremated him and built a stupa on Longshou Hill, next to where Fotuoboli's relics were buried, to the right of the tomb of the Empress Nuwa. On the tenth day of the tenth month of that year, they moved his remains into the stupa.
His disciples Langzhi, Daoxun, and Ruyi missed their teacher's virtues and never stopped making offerings to him.
The Imperial Attendant and Pillar of the State, Tian Shui Zhao Sikang, ordered the monk Shanyun to write a stele at the stupa site.
There was Shi Fayan of Lingzhi Temple in Qiantang, whose secular surname was Feng and who was originally from Changle.
He followed his grandfather to do business in Jiangdong and thus became a person of Qiantang.
His father and son were both named Yuan, and they inherited the family business of wearing official caps and robes.

However, he delved into the studies of the hundred schools of thought, and with determination aspired to be like VimalakÄ«rti in responding to situations. He often invited Chan masters to his home to discuss the Dharma, and in a separate room he made offerings, wishing to be reborn in the Pure Land.
After a long time, he was born into a family, and his extraordinary nature was divinely revealed.
As soon as he was able, he put on the robes and sought to leave the mundane world. His father firmly did not hold him back.
He shaved his head and received the full precepts, and explored the three vehicles, as if they were in the palm of his hand.

But his nature was always upright and aloof. In the deep valley of this temple, which is truly on the sunny side of the Zhejiang River, he built a hermitage far away from the monastery, and spent his days in meditation.
At that time, those with the same aspiration came to his door to seek his guidance. He followed the situation and pointed the way, and many attained realization.

On the thirteenth day of the twelfth month in the second year of Tianbao, at the beginning of dawn, he told his attendant to sit upright and suddenly passed away, at the age of sixty-five, with less than twenty years as a monk.
At that time, the mountain birds cried sadly, and the clouds and mist were gloomy. The donors from far and near wept like a wall.
On the nineteenth day of that month, he was buried on a mountain by the side of the temple.
He had disciples such as Yu Fajie, his son Huai Fu, and his grandson Xixiu, who had long been devoted to him. They built the pagoda and managed the affairs, all from their own families.
The pagoda was destroyed during the Huichang period. Now only the foundation remains.
The stone stele has been lost. Alas!

Biography of Xuan Su of Youqi Temple in Runzhou of the Tang Dynasty. Biography of Xuan Su of Youqi Temple in Runzhou of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Xuan Su, whose courtesy name was Dao Qing, was a layman surnamed Ma, and was a person from Yanling, Runzhou.
He had extraordinary abilities since birth. From a young age, he was deeply benevolent and was raised in a peaceful and quiet manner.
In his childhood, he aspired to return to the Buddhist order, and his parents followed his wishes and let him leave home.
In the Ruyi year, he began to follow the monastic rules and was registered at Changshou Temple in Jiangning.

After receiving full ordination, the light of his precepts shone brightly, and the water of his meditation was calm and rippling. His thoughts penetrated the profound and subtle, and his practice surpassed that of ordinary people.
Having understood the emptiness of form, he always admired the great masters.
In his later years, he entered Qixia Temple in the south, where he served Chan Master Wei for many years, striking the bell loudly.
Wei taught him the supreme Dharma, and he attained the unchanging essence.

From then on, he humbled himself in ascetic practice, nourishing himself with simplicity and harmony. He wore a coarse robe on his body, unchanged in cold or heat, and had no joy or anger towards the noble, the humble, or those who hated or loved him. At that time, he was called the Bodhisattva of Childlike Conduct.
As his practice of the Way became lofty, people rarely saw him.

In the Kaiyuan era, monk Wang secretly invited him to Jingkou. The prefectural governor Wei Xian invited him to stay at Helin Temple. The four groups of Buddhists returned to their sincerity, filling the temple grounds.
He wore plain robes and sat on an empty bed, never leaving his room. Even when kings and nobles bowed to him, he remained unmoved.
He regarded worldly fame and profit as illusory.

Suddenly one day, a butcher came to pay respects, and he was moved to realize the truth, repent his past sins, and request Su Ming to accept his offerings. He then joyfully accepted the invitation and went to his house.
The common people were shocked and all exclaimed, How strange!
Su said:
The Buddha-nature is the same, how can there be any difference in non-arising?
I will only save those who can be saved, what is so strange about that?
In the beginning of the Tianbao era, people in Wu and Yue looked up to him as if he were the Buddha descending to be born.
The Yangzhou monk Xixuan invited him to go north of the river, but he secretly ran away in the night.
In the dark month, it was difficult to cross the river, with its vast waves. He held onto the boat, aiming with the wind.
Suddenly there was a white light leading the way, and he rowed straight across, safely reaching the other shore.
The people of Chu rejoiced, saying the Buddha's sun was shining again.
People from the entire prefecture rushed to the ferry, gathering there.
The crowds of people were so dense that there was no room to stand. They took off their clothes and offered them as donations, piling up like mountains and hills.
He did not briefly interfere with their thoughts, allowing them to fully cover the expenses of the field of compassion.
Li Yan, the Minister of Rites, served as the Prefect of Yangzhou. He was pious and sincere, and looked up to [Zhizhe] twice a day.
Before long, the monks and laypeople in Jingkou longed for the sound of the Dharma, and they sent a letter across the river, inviting him to return to the prefecture.
The two places argued and disputed, unable to decide where to follow him.
Li Yan said to people at the time:
Originally, I hoped to serve the Way, but it has turned into love and hatred.
Thus, he followed the invitation and returned to Nanzhou. His influence on people and admiration for his virtue were rarely matched.
On the eleventh day of the eleventh month of the eleventh year of Tianbao, he passed away peacefully in the middle of the night, at the age of eighty-five.
His grief moved people's hearts and deeply shocked the city.
On the twenty-first day of that month, his whole body was enshrined and a pagoda was built on the western side of Mount Huanghe, where he had resided.
The prefect and magistrate all observed the rites of mourning for their teacher, leading the people to express their grief, the sound shaking the rivers and lakes.
In the place where he used to sit in meditation in the temple, a tall pine tree bent over like a canopy, and when moved to another tree, it returned to its original position.
Also, on the evening of his passing away, the twin paulownia trees in front of his room withered for no reason.
Those who knew him took this as a change like the twin sal trees.
But the wonderful principle of the true vehicle is beyond appearances and difficult to conceive;
Auspicious spiritual omens must have a response.
The sutra says:
Following conditions and responding to them is precisely this matter.
There were two of his disciples, Faguan and Fachin of Wu Prefecture, these two great beings who greatly illuminated Dao Yuan, all with separate biographies.

The disciples who received the bodhisattva precepts included Qi Yan, the Minister of the Court of Imperial Entertainments, Liang Qing, the Governor of Guangzhou, Xu Qiao, the Prefect of Runzhou, Wei Zhaoli of Jingzhao, Han Shang, the Palace Attendant, Li Dan, the Palace Attendant for Ceremonials, and Cui Lingqin of the Ministry of Rites. They were all renowned figures in the Way, and all regarded him as their teacher. They also once inquired about the Way at Jingshan, just like Zichuan of Lezheng did with Confucius.
They washed their hearts and looked up to him, but the heavens were even higher.
There were many who understood the profound truth by reflecting on the clear mind.
Later, during the Taihe period, they admired his legacy from afar and revered his virtuous conduct. He was posthumously titled the Great Vinaya Chan Master, and his pagoda was named Taihe Dabao.
Later people often referred to him by his secular surname as Mazu, or sometimes by both his given and surname as Maming.
The author says:
The one who ascended to the heavens said that all ordained sons have the surname Shi. This is in agreement with the later arrival of the Agamas. Is this not something to be pursued?
Master Su must have had a reason for calling him by his secular surname.

Alas, even the numerous flourishing Dharma heirs could not stop this erroneous title. It can be known that Master Su's name flew like wings, and the four seas looked up to him, so he ascended to the secular realm.

Shi Huizhong, with the secular surname Ran, was a person from Zhuchi in Yuezhou.
Who can distinguish the Jiazi year?
Some say it was in his later years.
His skin was as fair as snow, and his spirit was lofty and refreshing.
From a young age, he loved to study. He received the Dharma from Shuangfeng. Silently perfecting the truth, he received the mind seal.

His actions had no fixed form. He visited famous mountains, such as Wuling, Luofu, Siming, Tianmu, Baiya, and Yudi. The purple pavilion touched the sky. Sometimes he peacefully resided under pine trees for ninety days, sometimes he rested in emptiness and contemplated in samÄdhi.
Having hung the bright moon of precepts, one also purifies the mind like a lapis lazuli; having already crossed the threshold of meditation, one does not give rise to the view of non-arising.
It is as lofty as Mount Sumeru, unshakable by the eight winds;
As clear as a pure mirror, where do myriad forms hide?
If I can stay, then I will befriend the deer among the thousand peaks of Mount Wudang;
If I can go, then I will beg for alms among the people along the single path of Tiger Creek.
I have traveled through Wu and Chu, and have arrived at the Shunyang River.
I have chosen to live in the forests and springs of Dangzi for over forty years;
Deeply entering the holy concentration of the Dharma King, with its eighty thousand vast gates.
The sound of the Way is vast, and the strength is full!

In the Kaiyuan era, the Prefect, former Secretariat Director and Duke of Opening the State Wang Ju, and the Magistrate, Director of the Court of Imperial Sacrifices Zhao Yizhen, believed that the pool was clear, and heard the wind with delight. Zong was erudite and well-versed in etymology, extensively delving into sutras and precepts. Who can rival him in subduing demons and restraining outsiders?

One cannot be intimidated by his authority, nor swayed by his benefits. He eats at sunrise, and contemplates the moon. The clear wind blows frost, and his firm integrity surpasses bamboo. His words are concise and his reasoning is profound, toppling the banners of arrogance.

The wonderful cannot be transmitted, many flowers but few fruits. In the world, there are those who grasp pebbles in the water, thinking they have obtained a precious lapis lazuli;

Therefore, there is the teaching of transcending Vairocana, causing them not to seek the Buddha;
Surpassing the talk of the Dharma body, enabling them to be unstained by the true nature.
How can Vairocana be transcended and the Dharma body be surpassed?
Therefore, the mind of emptiness unifies with the principle of emptiness. Subtle falsehoods are like clouds and mists, while the thorough understanding of the school is like the sun and moon.
The carriage of the court official arrived, but An Chan remained unmoving. He received the crown prince's obeisance, still dignified as before.
This is what is meant by the ancients not welcoming the prince for seven steps, bringing blessings to the ruler of ten thousand chariots. How could it be limited to the hundred officials alone?

Emperor Suzong, in the summer of the Dingyou year, heard of his high virtue. On the 16th day of the first month of the second year of Shangyuan, he ordered the Imperial Attendant Sun Zhaoxin to welcome him with a horse-drawn carriage. His handwritten edict said:
The Emperor believes and asks: I have heard that the supreme vehicle of the TathÄgata is used to bring peace to the Central Land, and great beings benefit others and help all beings.

The master, with the Dharma mirror hanging high, expounds in one voice. The secret treasury is opened, and the realm enters the perfect brightness. Great compassion is never tired of ferrying and bridging, and the utmost goodness must be clear in benefiting others.
The entrustment of the Venerable Hero is indeed upon me.
I wish to proclaim the wonderful function with the peace of the Way, to greatly increase blessings and moisture, and extend to the great trichiliocosm.
Transmit the mysterious pearl of the illusory elephant, and pull out the poisonous arrow of deep delusion. The good conditions are here, do not consider it troublesome.
Come on foot, the capital is not far.
The mind has been purified for a long time, matching my empty mind.
Spring is cold, is the master safe and well?
The letter sent did not mention much.

Zhuang was always of the opinion that the Way is present everywhere, and the capital is no different from the countryside. He finally took high steps into the palace and led [Zhuang] to the main hall.
When the frost-covered staff first descended, the sun shone on the dragon robe, and heavenly incense was burned, with the wind blowing the feathered canopy.
At that time, Zhuang was at the forefront, engaging in martial arts, and the divine appearance was solemn and proper.
The emperor admired him and treated him with the courtesy of a teacher.
He discussed the essentials of governing the country and expounded the style of Tang Yao and Yu Shun.
When the emperor heard this, he was startled and sat in front of his knees.
The nine dragons sprinkled lotus flower water, and the myriad chariots drank the taste of ghee.
From this point on, he was carried on shoulders to the palace, sat and discussed the Way, not constrained by the established rites.
He was then ordered by the Cavalry Attendant Zhu Guanghui to reside at Qianfu Temple.
The Minister of State Affairs Cui Huan followed him to inquire about the ferry, and the principles resonated with his mind, being discussed in the court and the countryside.
Those who recognized the truth often visited him.
When Emperor Baoying came to the throne, he ruled the country with filial piety, not changing the previous favor, opening up the sky of a myriad of miles, as if seeing the moon of the three rivers.
Moreover, he ordered the palace attendant Yuan Shouhong to welcome him to Guangzhai Temple near the capital, where incense and food came like clouds, and purple robes were bestowed from heaven.

Although envoys guarded the Chan master's gate and did not let him in, jade and silk from the imperial court filled the courtyard, he regarded them as bubbles and saw them as dreams, calmly entrusting himself to the joy of nature.
It can be said that not returning to Luofu is called sitting in meditation;
only after going far to Shuangfeng can one begin to understand non-arising.
The embryo of becoming a sage is in this, and thus the myriad practices are all initiated and the thousand gates are unobstructed in the mind.

Then the drum of Tuá¹£ita has no form yet makes sound, and the lute of the asuras produces music without being played. The fragrance spreads to the Heavenly Lord, and flower rain falls on the Empty King, seen in loyalty. Master Si often said:

Thus, he petitioned to establish Taiyi Yanchang Temple on Wudang Mountain, and Xiangyan Changshou Temple in Partyzi Valley on Baiya Mountain, each requesting a copy of the Buddhist canon, and monks to protect and uphold it.
The imperial portraits of the two sages will be enshrined in Wudang.
The king's words are truly acceptable, and the authorities will follow suit.
Although the Monkey River and Goose Pagoda have not yet been adorned on the central peak,
The thatched roof and wooden door will be named after the Buddhist temple.

The imperial edict inscribed on the plaque, with the phoenix-like turns and magpie-like flights, the mountains and rivers shine brightly, and the black and white rejoice, thinking that the golden hall can be expected, seeing that the jade terrace is not far away.

In the eighth year of Dali, he again petitioned to select monks from famous mountains all over the country who were knowledgeable in sutras, precepts, and Chan, and add them to the three and seven people.
